Description: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York and the U.S. Department of Health and Human Services announced a $60 million settlement of a civil fraud lawsuit against Accredo Health Group concerning an alleged kickback scheme with Novartis Pharmaceuticals.
Agency: U.S. Attorney-Southern District of New York

Description: Bravo Health Pennsylvania, Inc. agreed to pay $225,000 for allegedly violating the Civil Monetary Penalties Law by providing medical records to the OIG's Office of Audit Services in connection with an OAS audit that were intentionally altered prior to their submission or resubmission.
Agency: Health & Human Services Department Office of Inspector General

Description: Medco Health Solutions agreed to pay the United States $155 million plus interest to settle allegations that the Parsippany, N.J.-based company submitted false claims to the government, solicited and accepted kickbacks from pharmaceutical manufacturers to favor their drugs, and paid kickbacks to health plans to obtain business.

Medco Health Solutions Inc., a wholly-owned subsidiary of the pharmacy benefit manager Express Scripts Holding Company, agreed to pay $7.9 million to settle allegations that it engaged in a kickback scheme in violation of the False Claims Act.

Description: Accredo Health Group, Inc. agreed to pay just under $15 million as part of the settlement of multistate litigation alleging that it recommended the drug Exjade to Medicaid patients in exchange for kickbacks from Novartis Pharmaceuticals Corporation, which marketed the drug. This was part of a $60 million settlement that also involved the federal government; see the Violation Tracker entry at https://violationtracker.goodjobsfirst.org/violation-tracker/-accredo-health-group

To resolve a case involving allegations of unfair health insurance reimbursement rates, CIGNA agreed to pay $10 million to a qualified nonprofit organization that would establish a new, independent database to help determine fair out-of-network reimbursement rates for consumers throughout the United States.

CIGNA agreed to pay $870,388 in settlement of allegations it paid commissions to a broker in connection with the state employee dental plan, which was explicitly disallowed by the state when it was soliciting bids.

Express Scripts and CIGNA agreed to pay a total of $27 million to settle allegations that they switched prescription drugs for benefit plan subscribers without telling them. The announcement did not specify how much each of the companies would pay. Here we assume they split the amount equally between them.

Pharmacy benefit manager Express Scripts agreed to pay $9.5 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that it engaged in unfair business practices by not clearly disclosing details about its practices relating to switching drugs when filling prescriptions.

Express Scripts and CIGNA agreed to pay a total of $27 million to settle allegations that they switched prescription drugs for benefit plan subscribers without telling them. The announcement did not specify how much each of the companies would pay. Here we assume they split the amount equally between them.
Life insurance of North America agreed to pay an additional $1.5 million in restitution to settle allegations it had not provided all the consumer relief required by a previous settlement.
Life Insurance of North America agreed to pay over $1.7 million in settlement of allegations it deceptively marketed health insurance plans that did not comply with state mandated requirements.

The California Attorney General announced that Medco agreed to pay $2.75 million and change internal procedures to settle claims regarding its engagement of Alfred Villalobos to assist it in securing a CalPERS contract in 2005.

Medco Health Solutions agreed to pay $29.1 million to settle multistate litigation alleging that the company encouraged prescribers to switch their patients to cheaper drugs, a practice that financially benefitted Medco but often did not provide savings for patients and their health care plans.
overcharging the State Teachers Retirement System
Info Source: Attorney General Petro Wins $7.8 Million Verdict Against Merck, Medco for Defrauding Teachers' Pension System, US States News, December 20, 2005 (via Nexis).

Company: Cigna HealthCare of New Hampshire Inc.

Description: Order Directing Remediation and Assessing Penalties #A07-34, April 25, 2007; CIGNA began to nonrenew optional benefit riders regarding small employer plans starting July 1, 2006 but the notices issued to employers differed from the specimen notice approved by the Department; CGLI and CIGNA provided small employer groups that were affected by the rider withdrawal with information encouraging them to select a CGLI PPO plan but failed to disclose the availability of a CIGNA HMO or HMO POS plan and did not explain the significant differences in benefits between the standard small employer HMO and HMO POS plans that were issued by CIGNA and the small employer PPO plans offered by CGLI; CGLI was required to make its PPO plan available without restrictive riders but failed to do so in many cases; CIGNA had 1,332 small employer HMO and HMO POS contracts in force as of June 30, 2006, which employers were advised that they only had the option to renew into CGLI, and in addition, as of March 26, 2007, CGLI offered and issued CGLI PPO plans containing restrictive riders to approximately 791 new small employer groups.  Order #A07-34 requests remedial relief to restore coverages and benefits to approximately the degree that would have likely existed had CIGNA and CGLI properly made available to employers required options and plan choices.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance

Company: CIGNA Healthcare of New Jersey, Inc.
Description: Insurers withdraw their contest to Order #A07-34, imposing sanctions in connection with practices regarding nonrenewal of optional benefit riders for certain small employer plans and offers to obtain new coverage.  Remediation was made to affected small employer members.
Agency: New Jersey Department of Banking & Insurance
